data-testid="headline">Crypto Enthusiasts Meet Their Match: Angry Gamers</h1></div><p class="css-1b6a17a e1wiw3jv0">Game publishers are offering NFTs, but skeptical gamers smell a moneymaking scheme class="css-aknsld e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><span class="css-1baulvz" itemProp="name"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/mike-isaac" class="css-mrorfa e1jsehar0">Mike Isaac</a></span> and <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemProp="name"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/kellen-browning" class="css-mrorfa e1jsehar0">Kellen Browning</a></span></p><div class="css-8atqhb"><p class="css-1hqgqgn e1wtpvyy0">Mike Isaac, who has been playing the video game Escape From Tarkov, reports on Facebook and Silicon Valley. Kellen Browning, who has been playing Age of Empires I, covers the games industry.</p></div></div></div><ul class="css-1u1psjv epjyd6m3"><li class="css-ccw2r3 epjyd6m2"><time dateTime="2022-01-19T12:07:36-05:00" class="css-ld3wwf e16638kd2"><span class="css-1sbuyqj e16638kd3">Published <!-- -->Jan. 15, 2022</span><span class="css-233int e16638kd4">Updated <!-- -->Jan. 19, 2022</span></time></li></ul></div></div></div><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">SAN FRANCISCO — For years, Christian Lantz has played S.T.A.L.K.E.R., a first-person shooter game set in a post-apocalyptic Ukraine that became a cult hit for its immersive role playing. So when the 18-year-old high schooler heard a sequel was coming this year, he knew he had to buy it.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">That was until GSC Game World, the Ukrainian company behind the computer game, announced last month that the new S.T.A.L.K.E.R. would incorporate the crypto-based assets known as <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/11/arts/design/what-is-an-nft.html" title="">nonfungible tokens</a>, or NFTs. In the new game, GSC said, players could buy and sell NFTs of items like clothing for their in-game characters. The company heralded the move as a “transformative step” toward the virtual world known as <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/30/technology/metaverse-virtual-reality-big-tech.html" title="">the metaverse</a>.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Mr. Lantz was incensed. He joined thousands of fans on Twitter and Reddit who raged against NFTs in S.T.A.L.K.E.R.’s sequel. The game maker, they said, was simply looking to squeeze more money out of its players. The backlash was so intense that GSC quickly <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/stalker_thegame/status/1471620399997886472?s=20" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">reversed itself</a> and abandoned its NFT plan.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“The studio was abusing its popularity,” Mr. Lantz, who lives in Ontario, said. “It’s so obviously being done for profit instead of just creating a beautiful game.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-1l3p632 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><picture><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: (min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 1dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 96dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2022/01/16/business/00NFT-GAMERS2/00NFT-GAMERS2-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale&width=1800"/><img alt="A still from &ldquo;S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2: Heart of Chernobyl.&rdquo; The game&rsquo;s maker recently abandoned a plan to add NFTs to the game." class="css-r3fift" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2022/01/16/business/00NFT-GAMERS2/00NFT-GAMERS2-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale" 1005px) 60vw, 100vw" decoding="async" width="600" height="337"/></picture></div><figcaption class="css-1l44abu ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">A still from “S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2: Heart of Chernobyl.” The game’s maker recently abandoned a plan to add NFTs to the game.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>GSC Game World</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">For more than a year, crypto mania has been at a fever pitch. Cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin and Ethereum have soared in value. Crypto-based assets like <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/24/technology/nft-column-blockchain.html" title="">NFTs</a> have <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/11/arts/design/nft-auction-christies-beeple.html" title="">taken off</a>. Jack Dorsey, a Twitter founder, recently renamed one of his companies Block in honor of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/26/technology/what-is-blockchain.html" title="">the blockchain</a>, the distributed ledger system that powers digital currencies. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/11/style/melania-trump-white-hat-auction.html" title="">Melania Trump</a> has auctioned off her own NFTs. Proponents hope that blockchain will revolutionize industries, from finance to social media to art.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">But to some, the crypto craze has gone too far, too fast. Skeptics argue that cryptocurrencies and related assets like NFTs are digital Ponzi schemes, with prices artificially inflated beyond their true value. Some question whether cryptocurrencies and the blockchain, which are slippery concepts, have any long-term utility.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Nowhere has there been more unhappiness than in the games community, where clashes over crypto have increasingly erupted between users and major game studios like Ubisoft, Square Enix and Zynga. In many of the encounters, the gamers have prevailed — at least for now.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“People are being sold buzzwords,” said Mutahar Anas, a gamer and YouTuber with three million subscribers. Those pushing NFTs in games, he said, are “trying to sell you snake oil.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">In recent months, at least half a dozen game studios have revealed plans to add NFTs to their games or said they were considering doing so. The <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/12/magazine/nft-art-crypto.html" title="">digital assets</a>, which are verified by blockchain technology, give proof of authenticity and ownership. That provides gamers with unique digital items, game makers said, which can enrich those that sell the NFTs in online marketplaces. Game publishers said NFTs could also potentially be transferred among games in the future, meaning items from one games franchise could affect gameplay in another.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">But players said they see the moves as a blatant cash grab.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“I just hate that they keep finding ways to nickel-and-dime us in whatever way they can,” said Matt Kee, 22, a gamer who took to Twitter in anger this month after Square Enix, which produces one of his favorite games, Kingdom Hearts, said it was pushing into NFTs. “I don’t see anywhere mentioning how that benefits the gamer, how that improves gameplay. It’s always about, ‘How can I make money off this?’”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-1l3p632 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-zjzyr8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:217.17777777777778px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-1l44abu ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">A still from “Kingdom Hearts III,” produced by Square Enix. The company recently said it planned to push into NFTs.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Disney/Square Enix</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Much of their resentment is rooted in the encroachment of micro transactions in video games. Over the years, game makers have found more ways to profit from users by making them pay to upgrade characters or enhance their level of play inside the games. Even if people had already paid $60 or more for a game upfront, they were asked to fork over more money for digital items like clothing or weapons for characters.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">In one well-known incident in 2006, the role-playing game “The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion” <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/events/horse-armor" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">charged users $2.50 for a set of armor</a> for their character’s horse.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“‘It was only a few bucks, but I remember thinking, ‘Why won’t they just give us the horse armor?’” said Eric Hild, 31, a beer brewer from Decorah, Iowa. “‘Why make us pay for it?’”</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Merritt K, a game streamer and editor at Fanbyte, a games industry site, said gamers’ antagonism toward the companies has built up over the last decade partly because of the growing number of micro transactions. So when game makers introduced NFTs as an additional element to buy and sell, she said, players were “primed to call this stuff out. We’ve been here before.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">That has led to bursts of gamer outrage, which have rattled the game companies. In December, Sega Sammy, the maker of the Sonic the Hedgehog game, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.segasammy.co.jp/english/ir/library/pdf/settlement/2022/managementmtg_main_qa_20211224_e.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">expressed reservations</a> about its NFT and crypto plans after “negative reactions” from users. Ubisoft, which makes titles like Assassin’s Creed, said that it had misjudged <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/SixerMason/status/1481691620118519810/photo/1" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">how unhappy its customers would be</a> after announcing an NFT program last month. A YouTube video about the move was disliked by more than 90 percent of viewers.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“Maybe we under-evaluated how strong the backlash could have been,” said Nicolas Pouard, a Ubisoft vice president who heads the French company’s new blockchain initiative.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Game companies said their NFT plans were not motivated by profit. Instead, they said, NFTs give fans something fun to collect and a new way for them to make money by selling the assets.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“It really is all about community,” said Matt Wolf, an executive at the mobile game maker Zynga, who is leading a foray into blockchain games. “We believe in giving people the opportunity to play to earn.”</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">The rush to embrace crypto in games has gathered steam over the past few years. Some developers began building games on the blockchain, making it easy for players to collect digital assets and prove they own them. One such game was <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/28/style/cryptokitties-want-a-blockchain-snuggle.html" title="">CryptoKitties</a>, a 2017 hit where players collected digital cats, some of which sold for more than $100,000. In the pandemic, blockchain-based games like Axie Infinity, where players make money by earning and selling NFTs, also became popular.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Bigger game studios are now trying to get in on the action, though some of their crypto plans remain vague.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Ubisoft was the first large game publisher to wade into crypto. In December, it announced an initiative known as Ubisoft Quartz, introducing three sets of NFTs in the form of digital equipment like helmets and guns. The NFTs were available for free in the shooter game Ghost Recon Breakpoint for players who had reached a certain level in the game. Gamers, the company said, could keep the items or sell them on third-party markets.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-1l3p632 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-zjzyr8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-1l44abu ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">A Ghost Recon Breakpoint game station at the Electronic Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles in 2019.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Adam S Davis/EPA, via Shutterstock</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">So far, 10,000 digital wallets — tools that allow people to store their crypto assets — have been connected to the Quartz platform, even though Ubisoft minted just 3,000 NFTs in its first batch, Mr. Pouard said. That suggested an appetite for more NFTs in the future, he said.</p><section role="complementary" class="css-14gh6yt" aria-label="A Guide to Cryptocurrency"><h2 class="css-ba3d02">A Guide to Cryptocurrency</h2><hr/><div id="storyline-context-container" aria-live="polite" aria-atomic="true"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Card 1 of 7</span><div data-scrolled-index="0" class="swiper css-1goft0b"><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="false"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>A glossary.<!-- --> </strong><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/25/technology/cryptocurrency-mainstream.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">Cryptocurrencies</a> have gone from a curiosity to a viable investment, making them almost impossible to ignore. If you are struggling with the terminology, let us help:</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>Bitcoin.<!-- --> </strong><span>A <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/01/technology/what-is-bitcoin-price.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">Bitcoin</a> is a digital token that can be sent electronically from one user to another, anywhere in the world. Bitcoin is also the name of the payment network on which this form of digital currency is stored and moved.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>Blockchain.<!-- --> </strong><span>A <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/27/business/dealbook/blockchains-guide-information.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">blockchain</a> is a database maintained communally, that <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/06/27/business/dealbook/blockchain-currencies.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">reliably stores digital information</a>. The original blockchain was the database on which all Bitcoin transactions were stored, but non-currency-based companies and governments are also trying to use blockchain technology to store their data.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>Cryptocurrencies.<!-- --> </strong><span>Since Bitcoin was <a href="https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/interactive/technology/bitcoin-timeline.html">first conceived in 2008</a>, thousands of other virtual currencies, known as <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/25/business/dealbook/bitcoin-cash-split.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">cryptocurrencies</a>, have been developed. Among them are <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/01/technology/what-is-ethereum.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">Ether</a>, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/15/style/dogecoin-cryptocurrency-investment.html?searchResultPosition=2&action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">Dogecoin</a> and <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/21/technology/bitcoin-bitfinex-tether.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">Tether</a>.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>Coinbase.<!-- --> </strong><span>The first major cryptocurrency company to list its shares on a U.S. stock exchange, Coinbase is a platform that allows people and companies <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/14/business/how-did-coinbase-stock-do.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">to buy and sell various digital currencies</a>, including Bitcoin, for a transaction fee.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>Crypto finance.<!-- --> </strong><span>The development of cryptocurrencies spawned a parallel universe of alternative financial services, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/09/05/us/politics/cryptocurrency-explainer.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">known as Decentralized Finance, or DeFi</a>, allowing crypto businesses to move into traditional banking territory, including lending and borrowing.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>NFTs.<!-- --> </strong><span>A “nonfungible token,” or NFT, is <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/11/arts/design/what-is-an-nft.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">an asset verified using blockchain technology</a>, in which a network of computers records transactions and gives buyers proof of authenticity and ownership. NFTs make <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/01/arts/design/banksy-nft-loic-gouzer-particle.html?searchResultPosition=11&action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">digital artworks</a> unique, and therefore sellable.</span></p></div></div></div></div><div class="css-8r08w0"><ul class="css-1dxpste"><li class="css-cromoy" data-active="true"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li></ul><nav aria-controls="storyline-context-container" class="css-9yx14y"><span class="arrow-left css-bfw7ir" role="button" aria-label="Previous card" aria-disabled="true" tabindex="-1"></span><span class="arrow-right css-e7hrc3" role="button" aria-label="Next card" aria-disabled="false" tabindex="0"></span></nav></div></section><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Ubisoft eventually plans to take a cut of sales of future NFTs, Mr. Pouard added. “We’re moving from a business model focused on just a game to a business model focused on an ecosystem in which every player can be a stakeholder,” he said.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Zynga, which is set to be <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/10/business/take-two-zynga.html" title="">acquired by Take-Two</a>, hired Mr. Wolf, a games industry veteran, to lead a crypto effort in November. The goal was to create new games on the blockchain, making it easy for players to acquire, own and sell NFTs, Mr. Wolf said. He provided few details about how the effort would work, including whether the NFTs could be transferred between Zynga games.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“We’re still developing all that,” he said.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Other game companies have waded into NFTs, echoing how crypto can generate new wealth for users. This month, Yosuke Matsuda, Square Enix’s president, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.hd.square-enix.com/eng/news/2022/html/a_new_years_letter_from_the_president_2.html" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">wrote in an open letter</a> that creating blockchain games would allow players to make money. That would become “a major strategic theme” for the company, he said.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">But as the number of NFT announcements from game studios piled up, players became increasingly annoyed. After users rebelled against Sega Sammy’s crypto plans, one of its executives said in a management meeting last month, “If it is perceived as simple moneymaking, I would like to make a decision not to proceed.” (The effort is continuing.)</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Other game companies have come out against crypto. Phil Spencer, the head of Microsoft’s Xbox, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.axios.com/xbox-exploitive-nft-gaming-projects-cb3d885f-694c-462d-bcb1-a24c892db32f.html" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">told Axios in November</a> that some games centered on earning money through NFTs appeared “exploitative” and he would avoid putting them in the Xbox store. Microsoft declined to comment.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Valve, which owns the online game store <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://partner.steamgames.com/doc/gettingstarted/onboarding" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Steam, also updated its rules</a> last fall to prohibit blockchain games that allow cryptocurrencies or NFTs to be exchanged. Valve did not respond to a request for comment.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">And Tim Sweeney, the chief executive of Epic Games, the maker of the game Fortnite, said his company would steer clear of NFTs in its own games because the industry is riddled with “an intractable mix of scams.” (Epic <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/TimSweeneyEpic/status/1449146317129895938?s=20" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">will still allow</a> developers to sell blockchain games in its online store.)</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-cfo9c3"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">The blowback has affected more than just game studios. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/29/business/discord-server-social-media.html" title="">Discord</a>, the messaging platform popular with gamers, backtracked in November after users threatened to cancel their paid subscriptions over a crypto initiative. Jason Citron, Discord’s chief executive, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/jasoncitron/status/1457841222995693570?s=20" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">had teased the project</a> on Twitter, prompting the mutiny.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“While I’m optimistic that there’s a lot of cool stuff going on in the blockchain space, there’s also a lot of problems,” Mr. Citron said in an interview.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Mr. Kee, the gamer, said he would continue fighting game companies’ crypto efforts. The S.T.A.L.K.E.R. developer’s about-face on NFTs made him hopeful that other companies could be swayed through public opinion, he said.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“It gives me a good feeling that everyone is vocal against this,” he said. “Over the past 10 years, we’ve seen all sorts of these schemes come up, and we’re tired of it.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div></div></div></section><div></div><div></div><div></div><div></div><div><div id="bottom-wrapper" class="css-2fttua"><div id="bottom-slug" class="css-l9onyx"><p>Advertisement</p></div><a href="#after-bottom" class="css-1ly73wi">Continue reading the main story</a><div class="ad bottom-wrapper css-rfqw0c" id="bottom" If you are struggling with the terminology, let us help:\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Bitcoin.\",\"text\":\"A \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F01\u002Ftechnology\u002Fwhat-is-bitcoin-price.html\\\"\u003EBitcoin\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is a digital token that can be sent electronically from one user to another, anywhere in the world. Bitcoin is also the name of the payment network on which this form of digital currency is stored and moved.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Blockchain.\",\"text\":\"A \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2018\u002F06\u002F27\u002Fbusiness\u002Fdealbook\u002Fblockchains-guide-information.html\\\"\u003Eblockchain\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is a database maintained communally, that \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2018\u002F06\u002F27\u002Fbusiness\u002Fdealbook\u002Fblockchain-currencies.html\\\"\u003Ereliably stores digital information\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. The original blockchain was the database on which all Bitcoin transactions were stored, but non-currency-based companies and governments are also trying to use blockchain technology to store their data.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Cryptocurrencies.\",\"text\":\"Since Bitcoin was \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Farchive.nytimes.com\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002Ftechnology\u002Fbitcoin-timeline.html\\\"\u003Efirst conceived in 2008\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, thousands of other virtual currencies, known as \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F07\u002F25\u002Fbusiness\u002Fdealbook\u002Fbitcoin-cash-split.html\\\"\u003Ecryptocurrencies\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, have been developed. Among them are \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F01\u002Ftechnology\u002Fwhat-is-ethereum.html\\\"\u003EEther\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F05\u002F15\u002Fstyle\u002Fdogecoin-cryptocurrency-investment.html?searchResultPosition=2\\\"\u003EDogecoin\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F11\u002F21\u002Ftechnology\u002Fbitcoin-bitfinex-tether.html\\\"\u003ETether\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Coinbase.\",\"text\":\"The first major cryptocurrency company to list its shares on a U.S. stock exchange, Coinbase is a platform that allows people and companies \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F04\u002F14\u002Fbusiness\u002Fhow-did-coinbase-stock-do.html\\\"\u003Eto buy and sell various digital currencies\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, including Bitcoin, for a transaction fee.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Crypto finance.\",\"text\":\"The development of cryptocurrencies spawned a parallel universe of alternative financial services, \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F09\u002F05\u002Fus\u002Fpolitics\u002Fcryptocurrency-explainer.html\\\"\u003Eknown as Decentralized Finance, or DeFi\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, allowing crypto businesses to move into traditional banking territory, including lending and borrowing.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"NFTs.\",\"text\":\"A “nonfungible token,” or NFT, is \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F11\u002Farts\u002Fdesign\u002Fwhat-is-an-nft.html\\\"\u003Ean asset verified using blockchain technology\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, in which a network of computers records transactions and gives buyers proof of authenticity and ownership. NFTs make \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F12\u002F01\u002Farts\u002Fdesign\u002Fbanksy-nft-loic-gouzer-particle.html?searchResultPosition=11\\\"\u003Edigital artworks\u003C\u002Fa\u003E unique, and therefore sellable.\"}]}}]}]}","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Fstoryline\u002F3ebf0054-7462-4612-9373-db6d88e097b3","tone":"FEATURE","primaryAssets":[]},"Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2I0ZDAxZjdlLTNhNGEtNTZmZS04YTRmLWQ0MTQxZDFhZmEzNQ==.storylines.0":{"storyline":{"type":"id","generated":true,"id":"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2I0ZDAxZjdlLTNhNGEtNTZmZS04YTRmLWQ0MTQxZDFhZmEzNQ==.storylines.0.storyline","typename":"Storyline"},"__typename":"AssociatedStoryline","ruleName":"styln-crypto-business","testName":""},"ROOT_QUERY":{"workOrLocation({\"id\":\"\u002F2022\u002F01\u002F15\u002Ftechnology\u002Fcryptocurrency-nft-gamers.html\"})":{"type":"id","generated":false,"id":"Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2I0ZDAxZjdlLTNhNGEtNTZmZS04YTRmLWQ0MTQxZDFhZmEzNQ==","typename":"Article"}}},"config":{"gqlUrlClient":"https:\u002F\u002Fsamizdat-graphql.nytimes.com\u002Fgraphql\u002Fv2","gqlRequestHeaders":{"nyt-app-type":"project-vi","nyt-app-version":"0.0.5","nyt-token":"MIIBIjANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQEFAAOCAQ8AMIIBCgKCAQEAs+\u002FoUCTBmD\u002FcLdmcecrnBMHiU\"},"gqlFetchTimeout":4000,"disablePersistedQueries":false,"fastlyHeaders":{},"initialDeviceType":"smartphone","fastlyAbraConfig":{".ver":"8856.000","HOME_chartbeat":"0_Control","INT_cwv_v2_control_split":"","INT_cwv_reduce_vi_js_0222":"","INT_cwv_deferViHydration_0222":"","STORY_cwv_abra_alloc_0222":"","VIDEO_cwv_vhs_defer_1121":"","Wirecutter_Growth_DEMO":"1_grow_variant","x-nyt-int-cwv-ads":"unset"},"internalPreviewConfig":{"meter":undefined,"swg":undefined},"serviceWorkerFile":"service-worker-test-1646843914448.js"},"ssrQuery":{},"initialLocation":{"pathname":"\u002F2022\u002F01\u002F15\u002Ftechnology\u002Fcryptocurrency-nft-gamers.html","search":""}};</script>

oembed.title: Crypto Enthusiasts Meet Their Match: Angry Gamers
oembed.summary: Game publishers are offering NFTs, but skeptical gamers smell a moneymaking scheme and are fighting back.
oembed.author_name: By Mike Isaac and Kellen Browning
oembed.html: <iframe src="https://www.nytimes.com/svc/oembed/html/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2022%2F01%2F15%2Ftechnology%2Fcryptocurrency-nft-gamers.html" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true" title="Crypto Enthusiasts Meet Their Match: Angry Gamers" style="border:none;max-width:500px;min-width:300px;min-height:550px;display:block;width:100%;"></iframe>
oembed.thumbnail_credit: Stacy Kranitz for The New York Times

readabilityObject.title: Cryptocurrency Enthusiasts Meet Their Match: Angry Gamers
readabilityObject.content:
Game publishers are offering NFTs, but skeptical gamers smell a moneymaking scheme and are fighting back.

“I just hate that they keep finding ways to nickel-and-dime us in whatever way they can,” said Matt Kee, a gamer, about a game studio’s push into NFTs.Credit...Stacy Kranitz for The New York Times

  • 146

Mike Isaac and Kellen Browning

Mike Isaac, who has been playing the video game Escape From Tarkov, reports on Facebook and Silicon Valley. Kellen Browning, who has been playing Age of Empires I, covers the games industry.

  • Published Jan. 15, 2022Updated Jan. 19, 2022

SAN FRANCISCO — For years, Christian Lantz has played S.T.A.L.K.E.R., a first-person shooter game set in a post-apocalyptic Ukraine that became a cult hit for its immersive role playing. So when the 18-year-old high schooler heard a sequel was coming this year, he knew he had to buy it.

That was until GSC Game World, the Ukrainian company behind the computer game, announced last month that the new S.T.A.L.K.E.R. would incorporate the crypto-based assets known as nonfungible tokens, or NFTs. In the new game, GSC said, players could buy and sell NFTs of items like clothing for their in-game characters. The company heralded the move as a “transformative step” toward the virtual world known as the metaverse.

Mr. Lantz was incensed. He joined thousands of fans on Twitter and Reddit who raged against NFTs in S.T.A.L.K.E.R.’s sequel. The game maker, they said, was simply looking to squeeze more money out of its players. The backlash was so intense that GSC quickly reversed itself and abandoned its NFT plan.

“The studio was abusing its popularity,” Mr. Lantz, who lives in Ontario, said. “It’s so obviously being done for profit instead of just creating a beautiful game.”

For more than a year, crypto mania has been at a fever pitch. Cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin and Ethereum have soared in value. Crypto-based assets like NFTs have taken off. Jack Dorsey, a Twitter founder, recently renamed one of his companies Block in honor of the blockchain, the distributed ledger system that powers digital currencies. Melania Trump has auctioned off her own NFTs. Proponents hope that blockchain will revolutionize industries, from finance to social media to art.

But to some, the crypto craze has gone too far, too fast. Skeptics argue that cryptocurrencies and related assets like NFTs are digital Ponzi schemes, with prices artificially inflated beyond their true value. Some question whether cryptocurrencies and the blockchain, which are slippery concepts, have any long-term utility.

Nowhere has there been more unhappiness than in the games community, where clashes over crypto have increasingly erupted between users and major game studios like Ubisoft, Square Enix and Zynga. In many of the encounters, the gamers have prevailed — at least for now.

“People are being sold buzzwords,” said Mutahar Anas, a gamer and YouTuber with three million subscribers. Those pushing NFTs in games, he said, are “trying to sell you snake oil.”

In recent months, at least half a dozen game studios have revealed plans to add NFTs to their games or said they were considering doing so. The digital assets, which are verified by blockchain technology, give proof of authenticity and ownership. That provides gamers with unique digital items, game makers said, which can enrich those that sell the NFTs in online marketplaces. Game publishers said NFTs could also potentially be transferred among games in the future, meaning items from one games franchise could affect gameplay in another.

But players said they see the moves as a blatant cash grab.

“I just hate that they keep finding ways to nickel-and-dime us in whatever way they can,” said Matt Kee, 22, a gamer who took to Twitter in anger this month after Square Enix, which produces one of his favorite games, Kingdom Hearts, said it was pushing into NFTs. “I don’t see anywhere mentioning how that benefits the gamer, how that improves gameplay. It’s always about, ‘How can I make money off this?’”

Much of their resentment is rooted in the encroachment of micro transactions in video games. Over the years, game makers have found more ways to profit from users by making them pay to upgrade characters or enhance their level of play inside the games. Even if people had already paid $60 or more for a game upfront, they were asked to fork over more money for digital items like clothing or weapons for characters.

In one well-known incident in 2006, the role-playing game “The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion” charged users $2.50 for a set of armor for their character’s horse.

“‘It was only a few bucks, but I remember thinking, ‘Why won’t they just give us the horse armor?’” said Eric Hild, 31, a beer brewer from Decorah, Iowa. “‘Why make us pay for it?’”

Merritt K, a game streamer and editor at Fanbyte, a games industry site, said gamers’ antagonism toward the companies has built up over the last decade partly because of the growing number of micro transactions. So when game makers introduced NFTs as an additional element to buy and sell, she said, players were “primed to call this stuff out. We’ve been here before.”

That has led to bursts of gamer outrage, which have rattled the game companies. In December, Sega Sammy, the maker of the Sonic the Hedgehog game, expressed reservations about its NFT and crypto plans after “negative reactions” from users. Ubisoft, which makes titles like Assassin’s Creed, said that it had misjudged how unhappy its customers would be after announcing an NFT program last month. A YouTube video about the move was disliked by more than 90 percent of viewers.

“Maybe we under-evaluated how strong the backlash could have been,” said Nicolas Pouard, a Ubisoft vice president who heads the French company’s new blockchain initiative.

Game companies said their NFT plans were not motivated by profit. Instead, they said, NFTs give fans something fun to collect and a new way for them to make money by selling the assets.

“It really is all about community,” said Matt Wolf, an executive at the mobile game maker Zynga, who is leading a foray into blockchain games. “We believe in giving people the opportunity to play to earn.”

The rush to embrace crypto in games has gathered steam over the past few years. Some developers began building games on the blockchain, making it easy for players to collect digital assets and prove they own them. One such game was CryptoKitties, a 2017 hit where players collected digital cats, some of which sold for more than $100,000. In the pandemic, blockchain-based games like Axie Infinity, where players make money by earning and selling NFTs, also became popular.

Bigger game studios are now trying to get in on the action, though some of their crypto plans remain vague.

Ubisoft was the first large game publisher to wade into crypto. In December, it announced an initiative known as Ubisoft Quartz, introducing three sets of NFTs in the form of digital equipment like helmets and guns. The NFTs were available for free in the shooter game Ghost Recon Breakpoint for players who had reached a certain level in the game. Gamers, the company said, could keep the items or sell them on third-party markets.

So far, 10,000 digital wallets — tools that allow people to store their crypto assets — have been connected to the Quartz platform, even though Ubisoft minted just 3,000 NFTs in its first batch, Mr. Pouard said. That suggested an appetite for more NFTs in the future, he said.

Ubisoft eventually plans to take a cut of sales of future NFTs, Mr. Pouard added. “We’re moving from a business model focused on just a game to a business model focused on an ecosystem in which every player can be a stakeholder,” he said.

Zynga, which is set to be acquired by Take-Two, hired Mr. Wolf, a games industry veteran, to lead a crypto effort in November. The goal was to create new games on the blockchain, making it easy for players to acquire, own and sell NFTs, Mr. Wolf said. He provided few details about how the effort would work, including whether the NFTs could be transferred between Zynga games.

“We’re still developing all that,” he said.

Other game companies have waded into NFTs, echoing how crypto can generate new wealth for users. This month, Yosuke Matsuda, Square Enix’s president, wrote in an open letter that creating blockchain games would allow players to make money. That would become “a major strategic theme” for the company, he said.

But as the number of NFT announcements from game studios piled up, players became increasingly annoyed. After users rebelled against Sega Sammy’s crypto plans, one of its executives said in a management meeting last month, “If it is perceived as simple moneymaking, I would like to make a decision not to proceed.” (The effort is continuing.)

Other game companies have come out against crypto. Phil Spencer, the head of Microsoft’s Xbox, told Axios in November that some games centered on earning money through NFTs appeared “exploitative” and he would avoid putting them in the Xbox store. Microsoft declined to comment.

Valve, which owns the online game store Steam, also updated its rules last fall to prohibit blockchain games that allow cryptocurrencies or NFTs to be exchanged. Valve did not respond to a request for comment.

And Tim Sweeney, the chief executive of Epic Games, the maker of the game Fortnite, said his company would steer clear of NFTs in its own games because the industry is riddled with “an intractable mix of scams.” (Epic will still allow developers to sell blockchain games in its online store.)

The blowback has affected more than just game studios. Discord, the messaging platform popular with gamers, backtracked in November after users threatened to cancel their paid subscriptions over a crypto initiative. Jason Citron, Discord’s chief executive, had teased the project on Twitter, prompting the mutiny.

“While I’m optimistic that there’s a lot of cool stuff going on in the blockchain space, there’s also a lot of problems,” Mr. Citron said in an interview.

Mr. Kee, the gamer, said he would continue fighting game companies’ crypto efforts. The S.T.A.L.K.E.R. developer’s about-face on NFTs made him hopeful that other companies could be swayed through public opinion, he said.

“It gives me a good feeling that everyone is vocal against this,” he said. “Over the past 10 years, we’ve seen all sorts of these schemes come up, and we’re tired of it.”

Kellen Browning, who has been playing Age of Empires I, covers the games industry.Published Jan. 15, 2022Updated Jan. 19, 2022SAN FRANCISCO — For years, Christian Lantz has played S.T.A.L.K.E.R., a first-person shooter game set in a post-apocalyptic Ukraine that became a cult hit for its immersive role playing. So when the 18-year-old high schooler heard a sequel was coming this year, he knew he had to buy it.That was until GSC Game World, the Ukrainian company behind the computer game, announced last month that the new S.T.A.L.K.E.R. would incorporate the crypto-based assets known as nonfungible tokens, or NFTs. In the new game, GSC said, players could buy and sell NFTs of items like clothing for their in-game characters. The company heralded the move as a “transformative step” toward the virtual world known as the metaverse.Mr. Lantz was incensed. He joined thousands of fans on Twitter and Reddit who raged against NFTs in S.T.A.L.K.E.R.’s sequel. The game maker, they said, was simply looking to squeeze more money out of its players. The backlash was so intense that GSC quickly reversed itself and abandoned its NFT plan.“The studio was abusing its popularity,” Mr. Lantz, who lives in Ontario, said. “It’s so obviously being done for profit instead of just creating a beautiful game.”ImageCredit...GSC Game WorldFor more than a year, crypto mania has been at a fever pitch. Cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin and Ethereum have soared in value. Crypto-based assets like NFTs have taken off. Jack Dorsey, a Twitter founder, recently renamed one of his companies Block in honor of the blockchain, the distributed ledger system that powers digital currencies. Melania Trump has auctioned off her own NFTs. Proponents hope that blockchain will revolutionize industries, from finance to social media to art.But to some, the crypto craze has gone too far, too fast. Skeptics argue that cryptocurrencies and related assets like NFTs are digital Ponzi schemes, with prices artificially inflated beyond their true value. Some question whether cryptocurrencies and the blockchain, which are slippery concepts, have any long-term utility.Nowhere has there been more unhappiness than in the games community, where clashes over crypto have increasingly erupted between users and major game studios like Ubisoft, Square Enix and Zynga. In many of the encounters, the gamers have prevailed — at least for now.“People are being sold buzzwords,” said Mutahar Anas, a gamer and YouTuber with three million subscribers. Those pushing NFTs in games, he said, are “trying to sell you snake oil.”In recent months, at least half a dozen game studios have revealed plans to add NFTs to their games or said they were considering doing so. The digital assets, which are verified by blockchain technology, give proof of authenticity and ownership. That provides gamers with unique digital items, game makers said, which can enrich those that sell the NFTs in online marketplaces. Game publishers said NFTs could also potentially be transferred among games in the future, meaning items from one games franchise could affect gameplay in another.But players said they see the moves as a blatant cash grab.“I just hate that they keep finding ways to nickel-and-dime us in whatever way they can,” said Matt Kee, 22, a gamer who took to Twitter in anger this month after Square Enix, which produces one of his favorite games, Kingdom Hearts, said it was pushing into NFTs. “I don’t see anywhere mentioning how that benefits the gamer, how that improves gameplay. It’s always about, ‘How can I make money off this?’”ImageCredit...Disney/Square EnixMuch of their resentment is rooted in the encroachment of micro transactions in video games. Over the years, game makers have found more ways to profit from users by making them pay to upgrade characters or enhance their level of play inside the games. Even if people had already paid $60 or more for a game upfront, they were asked to fork over more money for digital items like clothing or weapons for characters.In one well-known incident in 2006, the role-playing game “The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion” charged users $2.50 for a set of armor for their character’s horse.“‘It was only a few bucks, but I remember thinking, ‘Why won’t they just give us the horse armor?’” said Eric Hild, 31, a beer brewer from Decorah, Iowa. “‘Why make us pay for it?’”Merritt K, a game streamer and editor at Fanbyte, a games industry site, said gamers’ antagonism toward the companies has built up over the last decade partly because of the growing number of micro transactions. So when game makers introduced NFTs as an additional element to buy and sell, she said, players were “primed to call this stuff out. We’ve been here before.”That has led to bursts of gamer outrage, which have rattled the game companies. In December, Sega Sammy, the maker of the Sonic the Hedgehog game, expressed reservations about its NFT and crypto plans after “negative reactions” from users. Ubisoft, which makes titles like Assassin’s Creed, said that it had misjudged how unhappy its customers would be after announcing an NFT program last month. A YouTube video about the move was disliked by more than 90 percent of viewers.“Maybe we under-evaluated how strong the backlash could have been,” said Nicolas Pouard, a Ubisoft vice president who heads the French company’s new blockchain initiative.Game companies said their NFT plans were not motivated by profit. Instead, they said, NFTs give fans something fun to collect and a new way for them to make money by selling the assets.“It really is all about community,” said Matt Wolf, an executive at the mobile game maker Zynga, who is leading a foray into blockchain games. “We believe in giving people the opportunity to play to earn.”The rush to embrace crypto in games has gathered steam over the past few years. Some developers began building games on the blockchain, making it easy for players to collect digital assets and prove they own them. One such game was CryptoKitties, a 2017 hit where players collected digital cats, some of which sold for more than $100,000. In the pandemic, blockchain-based games like Axie Infinity, where players make money by earning and selling NFTs, also became popular.Bigger game studios are now trying to get in on the action, though some of their crypto plans remain vague.Ubisoft was the first large game publisher to wade into crypto. In December, it announced an initiative known as Ubisoft Quartz, introducing three sets of NFTs in the form of digital equipment like helmets and guns. The NFTs were available for free in the shooter game Ghost Recon Breakpoint for players who had reached a certain level in the game. Gamers, the company said, could keep the items or sell them on third-party markets.ImageCredit...Adam S Davis/EPA, via ShutterstockSo far, 10,000 digital wallets — tools that allow people to store their crypto assets — have been connected to the Quartz platform, even though Ubisoft minted just 3,000 NFTs in its first batch, Mr. Pouard said. That suggested an appetite for more NFTs in the future, he said.Ubisoft eventually plans to take a cut of sales of future NFTs, Mr. Pouard added. “We’re moving from a business model focused on just a game to a business model focused on an ecosystem in which every player can be a stakeholder,” he said.Zynga, which is set to be acquired by Take-Two, hired Mr. Wolf, a games industry veteran, to lead a crypto effort in November. The goal was to create new games on the blockchain, making it easy for players to acquire, own and sell NFTs, Mr. Wolf said. He provided few details about how the effort would work, including whether the NFTs could be transferred between Zynga games.“We’re still developing all that,” he said.Other game companies have waded into NFTs, echoing how crypto can generate new wealth for users. This month, Yosuke Matsuda, Square Enix’s president, wrote in an open letter that creating blockchain games would allow players to make money. That would become “a major strategic theme” for the company, he said.But as the number of NFT announcements from game studios piled up, players became increasingly annoyed. After users rebelled against Sega Sammy’s crypto plans, one of its executives said in a management meeting last month, “If it is perceived as simple moneymaking, I would like to make a decision not to proceed.” (The effort is continuing.)Other game companies have come out against crypto. Phil Spencer, the head of Microsoft’s Xbox, told Axios in November that some games centered on earning money through NFTs appeared “exploitative” and he would avoid putting them in the Xbox store. Microsoft declined to comment.Valve, which owns the online game store Steam, also updated its rules last fall to prohibit blockchain games that allow cryptocurrencies or NFTs to be exchanged. Valve did not respond to a request for comment.And Tim Sweeney, the chief executive of Epic Games, the maker of the game Fortnite, said his company would steer clear of NFTs in its own games because the industry is riddled with “an intractable mix of scams.” (Epic will still allow developers to sell blockchain games in its online store.)The blowback has affected more than just game studios. Discord, the messaging platform popular with gamers, backtracked in November after users threatened to cancel their paid subscriptions over a crypto initiative. Jason Citron, Discord’s chief executive, had teased the project on Twitter, prompting the mutiny.“While I’m optimistic that there’s a lot of cool stuff going on in the blockchain space, there’s also a lot of problems,” Mr. Citron said in an interview.Mr. Kee, the gamer, said he would continue fighting game companies’ crypto efforts. The S.T.A.L.K.E.R. developer’s about-face on NFTs made him hopeful that other companies could be swayed through public opinion, he said.“It gives me a good feeling that everyone is vocal against this,” he said. “Over the past 10 years, we’ve seen all sorts of these schemes come up, and we’re tired of it.”
